descriptionProfile: NatGeo photographer: environment, agriculture, Scotland, wee places. Studious. Nonconformist. Not so shy. Co-founder @eyeson_earth
NatGeo photographer: environment, agriculture, Scotland, wee places. Studious. Nonconformist. Not so shy. Co-founder

posts.description: Walking the cobbled streets on the old town of Tallinn, Estonia. Incredibly proud country feeling their fought for independence and guarding their charming heritage. Continuing our circumnavigation of the Baltic with National Geographic Expeditions. @natgeo @natgeocreative @natgeoexpeditions #lindbladexpeditions #estonia

The Danish island of Bornholm has four of these round churches. This one, the Østerlars Church, was built around 1160.  Still in use. @natgeo @natgeocreative #lindbladexpeditions #denmark  @natgeoexpeditions

The pretty harbor on Christiansø, Denmark. On a calm morning with the island to ourselves. The Brits once bombarded the island but were afraid of the guns in the tower-- but there weren't any! @natgeo @natgeocreative @natgeoexpeditions #lindbladexpeditions #denmark #island

Pulling into Christiansø, Denmark. Our first stop and our first chance on the Zodiacs. Great little island with less than a hundred people and history galore. Hardly half a mile long it is a perfect sort of stop for us island hoppers. More of the Baltic to come. @natgeo @natgeocreative @natgeoexpeditions #sweden #lindbladexpeditions

Morning on Nyhavn, Copenhagen as we were beginning our cruise of the Baltic. This trip will take us to the great cities and seaports. Lots of history and new territory for me, a huge bit of history I'm anxious to explore. @natgeo @lindbladexp #lindbladexpeditions #baltic @natgeoexpeditions

Amazing to be included in the NatGeo Creative print sale this week. I mean these people are my photographic heroes. Like the people who made these incredible images: Joel Sartore, Amy Toensing, Randy Olson, David Guttenfelder and the irrepressible John Stanmeyer. A nice way to remember Earth Day as well as all the years we have worked together. Visit the link in my profile to purchase a signed print of these images and more. @natgeocreative’s Flash Sale in honor of Earth Day runs from April 19th to April 22nd.

My image of The Storr on the Isle of Skye was first published in our “Edge of the World” story in the January 2010 issue of National Geographic magazine. I went there because the geology speaks so clearly of dramatic times, wonderful to behold even now, with the pinnacles of the Old Man of Storr booming high above the Sound of Raasay.  Now NatGeo Creative is making this available as a signed print (yes, I'll sign each one) for $100 from April 17th - April 22nd in honor of Earth Day. Click on the link in my profile to see all the signed prints featured in @natgeocreative’s Flash Sale.  #earthday #landscapes #scotland #isleofskye #basalt #geology @natgeo

Marching through the glens of Strathdon, the Lonach Highland and Friendly Society gathering is a classic scene from the summer Highland game season of Scotland. It was formed in 1823, mostly to preserve Highland dress and the Gaelic language (among others,) it harks back to an even earlier era when one of the main products of the Highlands was soldiers for the Scottish Regiments. It’s always the fourth Saturday of August and, to me, one of the finest of the games to be seen. There’s much more in our story on the Scottish Moors in the may issue of National Geographic. @natgeo @natgeocreative #scotland #lonach #lonachgames

The layered bens and glens of the Scottish Moors make the Cairngorms National Park a highlight for anyone seeking to understand this rich landscape. Our story in the May issue of National Geographic explores both the scenic wonders and the making of these lands, which owe as much to man-made influences as to nature. Even here you can see the stripes in the heather indicating that gamekeepers have been doing their jobs, burning the heather so that rich regrowth can nurture the red grouse. And tucked into the valleys are tree farms, a controversial land use in Scotland. But the hills themselves are magnificent and I was luck to see it that morning. #Scotland @natgeocreative #nature @natgeo

While I'm recalling the delights of the Aran Islands of Ireland it's fun to revisit the thrill of a visit to Dun Aengus on Inishmore. Creeping up to a 300 foot cliff will make a day memorable. The nonconformist in me likes that they have no guard rail. (They all survived.) @natgeo #nonconformist #ireland

Dún Dúchathair or simply Dúchathair (anglicized Doocaher), meaning "black stone ringfort" on Inishmore in the Aran Islands of Ireland. Over time the sea has battered the cliffs, eating into the island, until the fort is now just the wall across the promontory. It would have been a harsh place to seek refuge. @natgeo @natgeocreative #history

Dún Aonghasa (anglicized Dun Aengus) on Inishmore in the Aran Islands of Ireland.  The famous hill fort is protected by concentric walled defenses on one side and 300 foot sheer cliffs on the other.  Seeing it from a helicopter I got a view of both. It’s very old, of course, some of it going back to 1100 BC, maybe. But it never had a water supply so you can’t see how defenders would withstand a siege for long. I appreciate that they still haven’t built a fence along the cliff edge. It’s extremely scary but also thrilling. Nobody falls off. @natgeo @natgeocreative #ireland

The Aran Islands (Irish: Oileáin Árann) are indeed crisscrossed with many stone walls, some of which are very ancient. But there was also a proliferation of building in the last several centuries as families grew and fields were sub-divided and then divided again. The construction is drystane, meaning that there is no mortar used, so a great deal of skill is involved if they are to last. They are also constructed so the wind can pass through some, otherwise the fierce Atlantic gales would tear them down. It’s an inspiring place for a nonconformist like me. @natgeo @natgeocreative #ireland

Looking down on Irishman (Inis Meáin) in the Aran Islands (Irish: Oileáin Árann) you can connect the Iron Age with the modern world and see many of the steps in between.  Dún Chonchúir (Conor's Fort) is a ringfort started in pre-Christian times that is now surrounded by a maze of stone walls dividing fields and pastures. You can see how the road veered around as life developed in one continuous process from then till now.  And it’s quite possible that local folk living there now carry the genes of their ancestors who built the place. @natgeo @natgeocreative #ireland #history

Waffledagen here in my hometown of Lindsborg today. Waffle foolishness and waffle eating. These were two of my favorite waffles in Lucia Park. #waffledaylbk @natgeo @natgeocreative #lindsborg @lindsborgcvb

Thousands of miles of stone fences on the Aran Islands of Ireland are a testament to the hardy islanders who built them over centuries. I find it even more amazing is that they also created the soil by hauling sand and seaweed up from the beaches. @natgeo @natgeocreative #ireland #agriculture

Morning on Main Street, Lindsborg, Kansas. My home town. Sunrise greeted me when I came out of Blacksmith Coffee Shop this morning. Our shop, Small World Gallery, is in the middle there. That's where I show my work and plan my National Geographic stories. @natgeo @natgeocreative #kansas
